country.name: Turks and Caicos Islands
country.background: The islands were part of the UK's Jamaican colony until 1962, when they assumed the status of a separate crown colony upon Jamaica's independence. The governor of The Bahamas oversaw affairs from 1965 to 1973. With Bahamian independence, the islands received a separate governor in 1973. Although independence was agreed upon for 1982, the policy was reversed and the islands remain a British overseas territory.

location.desc: Caribbean, two island groups in the North Atlantic Ocean, southeast of The Bahamas, north of Haiti

area.comparison: 2.5 times the size of Washington, DC

geo.climate: tropical; marine; moderated by trade winds; sunny and relatively dry
geo.terrain: low, flat limestone; extensive marshes and mangrove swamps
geo.issues: limited natural freshwater resources, private cisterns collect rainwater

people.ethnic-groups: black 87.6%, white 7.9%, mixed 2.5%, East Indian 1.3%, other 0.7% (2001 census)
people.religions: Baptist 35.8%, Church of God 11.7%, Roman Catholic 11.4%, Anglican 10%, Methodist 9.3%, Seventh Day Adventist 6%, Jehovah's Witnesses 1.8%, other 14% (2001)

literacy.definition: age 15 and over has ever attended school

capital.name: Grand Turk (Cockburn Town)
capital.time-difference: UTC-5 (same time as Washington, DC during Standard Time)

government.legal-system: mixed legal system of English common law and civil law

executive.head-of-state: Queen ELIZABETH II (since 6 February 1952); represented by Governor Gordon WETHERELL (since 5 August 2008)
executive.head-of-government: Governor Gordon WETHERELL (since 14 August 2009); note - the office of premier is suspended by the Order in Council, effective 14 August 2009
executive.cabinet: under provisions of the Order in Council, the cabinet is suspended effective 14 August 2009 and replaced by an Advisory Council appointed by the governor
executive.elections: the monarchy is hereditary; governor appointed by the monarch

legislative.description: under provisions of the Order in Council, the unicameral House of Assembly is dissolved and all seats vacated for a period of up to two years; in the interim, a Consultative Forum, appointed by the governor, will be established
legislative.elections: last held on 9 February 2007 (next to be held by July 2011)
legislative.election-results: under provisions of the Order in Council, all seats in the House of Assembly are vacated

government.parties: People's Democratic Movement or PDM [Floyd SEYMOUR]; Progressive National Party or PNP [Michael Eugene MISICK]
government.flag: blue, with the flag of the UK in the upper hoist-side quadrant and the colonial shield centered on the outer half of the flag; the shield is yellow and displays a conch shell, a spiny lobster, and Turks Head cactus - three common elements of the islands' biota

economy.overview: The Turks and Caicos economy is based on tourism, offshore financial services, and fishing. Most capital goods and food for domestic consumption are imported. The US is the leading source of tourists, accounting for more than three-quarters of the 175,000 visitors that arrived in 2004. Major sources of government revenue also include fees from offshore financial activities and customs receipts.
economy.agriculture-products: corn, beans, cassava (tapioca), citrus fruits; fish

exports.commodities: lobster, dried and fresh conch, conch shells

imports.commodities: food and beverages, tobacco, clothing, manufactures, construction materials

telephones.assessment: fully digital system with international direct dialing
telephones.domestic: full range of services available; GSM wireless service available
telephones.international: country code - 1-649; the Americas Region Caribbean Ring System (ARCOS-1) fiber optic telecommunications submarine cable provides connectivity to South and Central America, parts of the Caribbean, and the US; satellite earth station - 1 Intelsat (Atlantic Ocean)

communications.broadcast: while there are no local terrestrial TV stations, broadcasts from the Bahamas can be received; multi-channel cable and satellite TV services are available; government-run radio network operates alongside private broadcasters with a total of about 15 stations broadcasting (2007)

manpower.notes: defense is the responsibility of the UK

issues.disputes: have received Haitians fleeing economic and civil disorder
issues.drugs: transshipment point for South American narcotics destined for the US and Europe
